conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the motion of the particle in both the magnetic field and the electric field.
We will break down the problem into two parts: the motion in the magnetic field and the motion in the electric field.
The particle is injected into the magnetic field from the origin O with an incident direction at a 45° angle to the y-axis.
The magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane and points inward.
The particle will follow a circular path in the magnetic field.
The radius of the circular path can be determined using the Lorentz force formula: qvB = mv^2/r.
The period of the circular motion is given by: T = 2πr/v = 2πm/qB.

Since the particle is injected at a 45° angle and the velocity is along the x-axis after exiting the magnetic field, the time taken to complete the circular motion must be such that the particle's path is consistent with the given coordinates.
The distance traveled in the magnetic field is the arc length corresponding to the angle through which the particle turns.
The particle must travel a distance such that it reaches the point P(3L, L) in the electric field.
The particle enters the electric field with a velocity v_0 along the x-axis.
The electric field is directed along the negative y-axis.
The particle will experience a constant acceleration in the negative y-direction.
The time taken to travel the distance L in the y-direction under constant acceleration is given by: y = 1/2 at^2.
The acceleration is due to the electric field E, so a = qE/m.
The distance L is traveled in the y-direction, so L = 1/2 (qE/m) t^2.
The time t is the same as the time taken to travel the distance 3L in the x-direction with constant velocity v_0, so 3L = v_0 t.
Solving for t, we get: t = 3L/v_0.
Substituting t into the equation for y, we get: L = 1/2 (qE/m) (3L/v_0)^2.
Simplifying, we get: L = 1/2 (qE/m) 9L^2/v_0^2.
